gurron2002 wrote:

> I am not sure when to use interfaces in the context of unit testing

Serious answer: whenever you need them.

> (I haven't actually implemented any unit tests yet, still figuring
> out how to refactor a design to best support unit testing).

Write the tests first, then refactor. Use JUnitX if you need access to 
private parts. Refactoring without tests is like walking a tightrope 
without a net. You can do it, but I wouldn't.

> Given a class Foo for which I want to create a mock object:
> 
> public class Foo {
>       public void doSomething() {
>             ...
>       }
> }
> 
> What is the better approach? To define an interface that only the
> mock object and the original object implement or to subclass Foo?

My advice: Extract the narrowest interface that could possibly work and 
implement it.

> I don't see a reason to to use an interface if it is only going to be
> implemented once (not counting the mock object, I can achieve the
> same overriding methods). Am I missing something? Or is it "good
> design" to specify the contract of a class with an interface even if
> there is not going to be more than one implementation ever?

First, you don't know how many implementations there will ever be. Even 
if you really think you know, you don't. That's nothing bad about you -- 
no-one knows.

Next, I am experimenting with the following Java implementation pattern. 
A refactoring, I think.

    * Replace private/public separation with interface/implementation 
separation.

In other words, rather than make methods private, which can hurt 
testing, extract a client interface and ship it to the client. Hide 
creating instances behind factories. In other words, do like JDBC, JMS, 
EJB...

I like it. Thoughts?
